trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic provides best practices for optimizing SQL Server performance in Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides best practices for optimizing SQL Server performance in Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: While running SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines, we recommend that you continue using the same database performance tuning options that are applicable to SQL Server in on-premises server environment.
trans-unit.target: While running SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines, we recommend that you continue using the same database performance tuning options that are applicable to SQL Server in on-premises server environment.

trans-unit.source: However, the performance of a relational database in a public cloud depends on many factors such as the size of a virtual machine, and the configuration of the data disks.
trans-unit.target: However, the performance of a relational database in a public cloud depends on many factors such as the size of a virtual machine, and the configuration of the data disks.

trans-unit.source: This paper is focused on getting the best performance for SQL Server on Azure VMs.
trans-unit.target: This paper is focused on getting the best performance for SQL Server on Azure VMs.

trans-unit.source: If your workload is less demanding, you might not require every optimization listed below.
trans-unit.target: If your workload is less demanding, you might not require every optimization listed below.

trans-unit.source: Consider your performance needs and workload patterns as you evaluate these recommendations.
trans-unit.target: Consider your performance needs and workload patterns as you evaluate these recommendations.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine size and storage account considerations
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine size and storage account considerations

trans-unit.source: For performance sensitive applications, it’s recommended that you use the following virtual machines sizes:
trans-unit.target: For performance sensitive applications, it’s recommended that you use the following virtual machines sizes:

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Enterprise Edition: DS3 or higher
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Enterprise Edition: DS3 or higher

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Standard and Web Editions: DS2 or higher
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Standard and Web Editions: DS2 or higher

trans-unit.source: For up-to-date information on supported virtual machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Sizes for Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For up-to-date information on supported virtual machine sizes, see <link><linkText>Sizes for Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In addition, we recommend that you create your Azure storage account in the same data center as your SQL Server virtual machines to reduce transfer delays.
trans-unit.target: In addition, we recommend that you create your Azure storage account in the same data center as your SQL Server virtual machines to reduce transfer delays.

trans-unit.source: When creating a storage account, disable geo-replication as consistent write order across multiple disks is not guaranteed.
trans-unit.target: When creating a storage account, disable geo-replication as consistent write order across multiple disks is not guaranteed.

trans-unit.source: Instead, consider configuring a SQL Server disaster recovery technology between two Azure data centers.
trans-unit.target: Instead, consider configuring a SQL Server disaster recovery technology between two Azure data centers.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>High Availability and Disaster Recovery for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>High Availability and Disaster Recovery for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Disks and performance considerations
trans-unit.target: Disks and performance considerations

trans-unit.source: When you create an Azure Virtual Machine, the platform will attach at least one disk to the VM for your operating system disk.
trans-unit.target: When you create an Azure Virtual Machine, the platform will attach at least one disk to the VM for your operating system disk.

trans-unit.source: This disk is a VHD stored as a page blob in storage.
trans-unit.target: This disk is a VHD stored as a page blob in storage.

trans-unit.source: You can also attach additional disks to your virtual machine as data disks, and these will be stored in storage as page blobs.
trans-unit.target: You can also attach additional disks to your virtual machine as data disks, and these will be stored in storage as page blobs.

trans-unit.source: There is another disk present in Azure Virtual Machines called the temporary disk.
trans-unit.target: There is another disk present in Azure Virtual Machines called the temporary disk.

trans-unit.source: This is a disk on the node that can be used for scratch space.
trans-unit.target: This is a disk on the node that can be used for scratch space.

trans-unit.source: Operating system disk
trans-unit.target: Operating system disk

trans-unit.source: An operating system disk is a VHD that you can boot and mount as a running version of an operating system and is labeled as C drive.
trans-unit.target: An operating system disk is a VHD that you can boot and mount as a running version of an operating system and is labeled as C drive.

trans-unit.source: Default caching policy on the operating system disk is Read/Write.
trans-unit.target: Default caching policy on the operating system disk is Read/Write.

trans-unit.source: For performance sensitive applications, we recommend that you use data disks instead of the operating system disk.
trans-unit.target: For performance sensitive applications, we recommend that you use data disks instead of the operating system disk.

trans-unit.source: See the section on Data Disks below.
trans-unit.target: See the section on Data Disks below.

trans-unit.source: Temporary disk
trans-unit.target: Temporary disk

trans-unit.source: The temporary storage drive, labeled as the D: drive, is not persisted to Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The temporary storage drive, labeled as the D: drive, is not persisted to Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Do not store your data or log files on the D: drive.
trans-unit.target: Do not store your data or log files on the D: drive.

trans-unit.source: Only store TempDB and/or Buffer Pool Extensions on the D drive when using the D-Series or G-Series Virtual Machines (VMs).
trans-unit.target: Only store TempDB and/or Buffer Pool Extensions on the D drive when using the D-Series or G-Series Virtual Machines (VMs).

trans-unit.source: Unlike the other VM series, the D drive in the D-Series and G-Series VMs is SSD-based.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the other VM series, the D drive in the D-Series and G-Series VMs is SSD-based.

trans-unit.source: This can improve the performance of workloads that heavily use temporary objects or that have working sets which don't fit in memory.
trans-unit.target: This can improve the performance of workloads that heavily use temporary objects or that have working sets which don't fit in memory.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Using SSDs in Azure VMs to store SQL Server TempDB and Buffer Pool Extensions</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Using SSDs in Azure VMs to store SQL Server TempDB and Buffer Pool Extensions</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Data Disk
trans-unit.target: Data Disk

trans-unit.source: Number of data disks for data and log files: At a minimum, use 2 P30 disks where one disk contains the log file(s) and the other contains the data file(s) and TempDB.
trans-unit.target: Number of data disks for data and log files: At a minimum, use 2 P30 disks where one disk contains the log file(s) and the other contains the data file(s) and TempDB.

trans-unit.source: For more throughput, you might require additional data disks.
trans-unit.target: For more throughput, you might require additional data disks.

trans-unit.source: To determine the number of data disks, you need to analyze the number of IOPS available for your data and log disk(s).
trans-unit.target: To determine the number of data disks, you need to analyze the number of IOPS available for your data and log disk(s).

trans-unit.source: For that information, see the tables on IOPS per <link><linkText>VM size</linkText><title></title></link> and disk size in the following article: <link><linkText>Using Premium Storage for Disks</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For that information, see the tables on IOPS per <link><linkText>VM size</linkText><title></title></link> and disk size in the following article: <link><linkText>Using Premium Storage for Disks</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you require more bandwidth, you can attach additional disks use Disk Striping.
trans-unit.target: If you require more bandwidth, you can attach additional disks use Disk Striping.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using Premium Storage, the recommendation is to add the maximum number of data disks supported by your <link><linkText>VM size</linkText><title></title></link> and use Disk Striping.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using Premium Storage, the recommendation is to add the maximum number of data disks supported by your <link><linkText>VM size</linkText><title></title></link> and use Disk Striping.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Disk Striping, see the related section below.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Disk Striping, see the related section below.

trans-unit.source: Caching policy: Enable read caching on the data disks hosting your data files and TempDB only.
trans-unit.target: Caching policy: Enable read caching on the data disks hosting your data files and TempDB only.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using Premium Storage, do not enable any caching on any data disks.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using Premium Storage, do not enable any caching on any data disks.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on configuring disk caching, see the following topics: <link><linkText>Set-AzureOSDisk</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Set-AzureDataDisk</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on configuring disk caching, see the following topics: <link><linkText>Set-AzureOSDisk</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Set-AzureDataDisk</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: NTFS allocation unit size: When formatting the data disk, it is recommended that you use a 64-KB allocation unit size for data and log files as well as TempDB.
trans-unit.target: NTFS allocation unit size: When formatting the data disk, it is recommended that you use a 64-KB allocation unit size for data and log files as well as TempDB.

trans-unit.source: Disk Striping: We recommend that you follow these guidelines:
trans-unit.target: Disk Striping: We recommend that you follow these guidelines:

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8/Windows Server 2012 or later, use <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8/Windows Server 2012 or later, use <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Set stripe size to 64 KB for OLTP workloads and 256 KB for data warehousing workloads to avoid performance impact due to partition misalignment.
trans-unit.target: Set stripe size to 64 KB for OLTP workloads and 256 KB for data warehousing workloads to avoid performance impact due to partition misalignment.

trans-unit.source: In addition, set column count = number of physical disks.
trans-unit.target: In addition, set column count = number of physical disks.

trans-unit.source: To configure a Storage Space with more than 8 disks you must use PowerShell (not Server Manager UI) to explicitly set the number of columns to match the number of disks.
trans-unit.target: To configure a Storage Space with more than 8 disks you must use PowerShell (not Server Manager UI) to explicitly set the number of columns to match the number of disks.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>, see <link><linkText>Storage Spaces Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure <link><linkText>Storage Spaces</linkText><title></title></link>, see <link><linkText>Storage Spaces Cmdlets in Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: For Windows 2008 R2 or earlier, you can use dynamic disks (OS striped volumes) and the stripe size is always 64 KB.
trans-unit.target: For Windows 2008 R2 or earlier, you can use dynamic disks (OS striped volumes) and the stripe size is always 64 KB.

trans-unit.source: Note that this option is deprecated as of Windows 8/Windows Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: Note that this option is deprecated as of Windows 8/Windows Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: For information, see the support statement at <link><linkText>Virtual Disk Service is transitioning to Windows Storage Management API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information, see the support statement at <link><linkText>Virtual Disk Service is transitioning to Windows Storage Management API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If your workload is not log intensive and does not need dedicated IOPs, you can configure just one storage pool.
trans-unit.target: If your workload is not log intensive and does not need dedicated IOPs, you can configure just one storage pool.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, create two storage pools, one for the log file(s) and another storage pool for the data file(s) and TempDB.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, create two storage pools, one for the log file(s) and another storage pool for the data file(s) and TempDB.

trans-unit.source: Determine the number of disks associated with each storage pool based on your load expectations.
trans-unit.target: Determine the number of disks associated with each storage pool based on your load expectations.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind that different VM sizes allow different numbers of attached data disks.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind that different VM sizes allow different numbers of attached data disks.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Sizes for Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Sizes for Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: I/O performance considerations
trans-unit.target: I/O performance considerations

trans-unit.source: The best results with Premium Storage are achieved when you parallelize your application and requests.
trans-unit.target: The best results with Premium Storage are achieved when you parallelize your application and requests.

trans-unit.source: Premium Storage is designed for scenarios where the IO queue depth is greater than 1, so you will see little or no performance gains for single-threaded serial requests (even if they are storage intensive).
trans-unit.target: Premium Storage is designed for scenarios where the IO queue depth is greater than 1, so you will see little or no performance gains for single-threaded serial requests (even if they are storage intensive).

trans-unit.source: For example, this could impact the single-threaded test results of performance analysis tools, such as SQLIO.
trans-unit.target: For example, this could impact the single-threaded test results of performance analysis tools, such as SQLIO.

trans-unit.source: Consider using <link><linkText>database page compression</linkText><title></title></link> as it can help improve performance of I/O intensive workloads.
trans-unit.target: Consider using <link><linkText>database page compression</linkText><title></title></link> as it can help improve performance of I/O intensive workloads.

trans-unit.source: However, the data compression might increase the CPU consumption on the database server.
trans-unit.target: However, the data compression might increase the CPU consumption on the database server.

trans-unit.source: Consider compressing any data files when transferring in/out of Azure.
trans-unit.target: Consider compressing any data files when transferring in/out of Azure.

trans-unit.source: Consider enabling instant file initialization to reduce the time that is required for initial file allocation.
trans-unit.target: Consider enabling instant file initialization to reduce the time that is required for initial file allocation.

trans-unit.source: To take advantage of instant file initialization, you grant the SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER) service account with SE_MANAGE_VOLUME_NAME and add it to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy.
trans-unit.target: To take advantage of instant file initialization, you grant the SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER) service account with SE_MANAGE_VOLUME_NAME and add it to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a SQL Server platform image for Azure, the default service account (NT Service\MSSQLSERVER) isn’t added to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a SQL Server platform image for Azure, the default service account (NT Service\MSSQLSERVER) isn’t added to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy.

trans-unit.source: In other words, instant file initialization is not enabled in a SQL Server Azure platform image.
trans-unit.target: In other words, instant file initialization is not enabled in a SQL Server Azure platform image.

trans-unit.source: After adding the SQL Server service account to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy, restart the SQL Server service.
trans-unit.target: After adding the SQL Server service account to the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy, restart the SQL Server service.

trans-unit.source: There could be security considerations for using this feature.
trans-unit.target: There could be security considerations for using this feature.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Database File Initialization</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Database File Initialization</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: autogrow is considered to be merely a contingency for unexpected growth.
trans-unit.target: autogrow is considered to be merely a contingency for unexpected growth.

trans-unit.source: Do not manage your data and log growth on a day-to-day basis with autogrow.
trans-unit.target: Do not manage your data and log growth on a day-to-day basis with autogrow.

trans-unit.source: If autogrow is used, pre-grow the file using the Size switch.
trans-unit.target: If autogrow is used, pre-grow the file using the Size switch.

trans-unit.source: Make sure autoshrink is disabled to avoid unnecessary overhead that can negatively affect performance.
trans-unit.target: Make sure autoshrink is disabled to avoid unnecessary overhead that can negatively affect performance.

trans-unit.source: If you are running SQL Server 2012, install Service Pack 1 Cumulative Update 10.
trans-unit.target: If you are running SQL Server 2012, install Service Pack 1 Cumulative Update 10.

trans-unit.source: This update contains the fix for poor performance on I/O when you execute select into temporary table statement in SQL Server 2012.
trans-unit.target: This update contains the fix for poor performance on I/O when you execute select into temporary table statement in SQL Server 2012.

trans-unit.source: For information, see this <link><linkText>knowledge base article</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information, see this <link><linkText>knowledge base article</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Move system databases (such as msdb and TempDB), backups and the default data and log directories of SQL Server to non-cached data disks to improve performance.
trans-unit.target: Move system databases (such as msdb and TempDB), backups and the default data and log directories of SQL Server to non-cached data disks to improve performance.

trans-unit.source: The following list highlights some SQL Server features that can help you to achieve better performance:
trans-unit.target: The following list highlights some SQL Server features that can help you to achieve better performance:

trans-unit.source: Backup to Azure storage: When performing backups for SQL Server running in Azure virtual machines, you can use SQL Server Backup to URL.
trans-unit.target: Backup to Azure storage: When performing backups for SQL Server running in Azure virtual machines, you can use SQL Server Backup to URL.

trans-unit.source: This feature is available starting with SQL Server 2012 SP1 CU2 and recommended for backing up to the attached data disks.
trans-unit.target: This feature is available starting with SQL Server 2012 SP1 CU2 and recommended for backing up to the attached data disks.

trans-unit.source: When you backup/restore to/from Azure storage, follow the recommendations provided at <link><linkText>SQL Server Backup to URL Best Practices and Troubleshooting and Restoring from Backups Stored in Azure Storage</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: When you backup/restore to/from Azure storage, follow the recommendations provided at <link><linkText>SQL Server Backup to URL Best Practices and Troubleshooting and Restoring from Backups Stored in Azure Storage</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: You can also automate these backups using <link><linkText>Automated Backup for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can also automate these backups using <link><linkText>Automated Backup for SQL Server in Azure Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Prior to SQL Server 2012, you can use <link><linkText>SQL Server Backup to Azure Tool</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Prior to SQL Server 2012, you can use <link><linkText>SQL Server Backup to Azure Tool</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This tool can help to increase backup throughput using multiple backup stripe targets.
trans-unit.target: This tool can help to increase backup throughput using multiple backup stripe targets.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server Data Files in Azure: This new feature, SQL Server Data Files in Azure, is available starting with SQL Server 2014.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server Data Files in Azure: This new feature, SQL Server Data Files in Azure, is available starting with SQL Server 2014.

trans-unit.source: Running SQL Server with data files in Azure demonstrates comparable performance characteristics as using Azure data disks.
trans-unit.target: Running SQL Server with data files in Azure demonstrates comparable performance characteristics as using Azure data disks.
